author: Megan Ellis
title: 'Cruelty is behind elephant rides'
text:
'Cruelty is behind elephant rides' Article By: Megan Ellis Fri, 18 Sep 2015 2:14 PM Share Your Email A baby elephant with its mother. Credit: flickr.com/ Mara 1 
An animal advocacy group has called for the end to elephant rides and tricks for tourists, saying that behind the scenes is a tragic situation. 
"Most tourists go on elephant rides because they love elephants. They don't know about the intense physical and psychological pain involved," World Animal Protection said in a report titled Breaking Africa's Elephants. 
"They will not be told that baby elephants are cruelly taken from their mothers, and their spirits harshly broken for training to give rides and perform tricks for tourists." 
The report focuses on the situation in Southern Africa, where elephant rides are plentiful. 
The organisation says that despite the claims of the elephant rides industry, all elephants used for entertainment go through an intensive process to break their spirits. 
This process includes restraining the elephants with chains or ropes and using bullhooks, whips and other objects in inflict pain on the elephant. The process often also involves food or water deprivation. 
"Elephant handlers in Southern Africa have confirmed to us that all young elephants undergo the same breaking process as used in Asia," World Animal Protection said. 
"This is despite the widespread claims of African elephant ride businesses that their elephants are 'trained' through a system of rewards such as molasses pellets." 
The organisation believes that if more tourists knew about the breaking process, they would not buy into the tourist gimmicks. 
It urged tourists to only visit ethical wildlife destinations and legitimate sanctuaries. 
"Ethical wildlife tourists can help end the unnecessary suffering of elephants by refusing to visit the parks that offer rides, shows and tricks," the organisation said. 
"Genuine elephant sanctuaries, such as the David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust, have animal welfare at the core of what they do. They will not use elephants in performances for tourists or allow the elephants to be ridden."
